data.title: B.C. gang hitman sentenced to life for murders as court hears from witness, parents of dead man
data.meta_description: Court hears emotional statements from parent of one murdered man and a witness who tried to help him
data.text:
Gang member previously found guilty of two counts of first degree murder was automatically sentenced to life in prison without parole for 25 years

Article content

A Brothers Keeper hitman was sentenced to life in prison on Thursday after a B.C. Supreme Court heard emotional statements from one victim’s family and a witness who said she was left “mentally distraught” and “broken.”

Tyrel Nguyen, wearing a light grey suit, his hair in long cornrow braids, shook his head when asked by Justice Miriam Gropper if he had anything to say after she delivered that sentence for two first-degree murders and two attempted murders.

Article content

Nguyen smiled at a friend sitting behind him in the public gallery and tapped his fist twice on his heart before putting on his jacket and walking out of the courtroom. His mother wiped her eyes in the front row.

A life sentence without a chance of parole for 25 years is automatic for planned or premeditated murders. Nguyen received four life sentences to be served concurrently.

In November, Gropper found Nguyen guilty of first-degree murder of rival gangster Randy Kang in Surrey on Oct. 27, 2017, and of Jagvir Singh Malhi, an unintentional target, on Nov. 12, 2018, in Abbotsford. He was also found guilty of attempted murder of Gary Kang, Randy’s brother, and associate Camilo Alonso, both on the night of Kang’s murder.

Earlier on Thursday, Crown prosecutor Joe Bellows read in court two victim statements, one from the parents of Malhi, a university student who was shot after being rear-ended by another vehicle.

Court was told his brother had been the intended victim.

Malhi’s parents said their son was a compassionate and caring young man who visited his ailing grandfather every day, was loved by his community and is still mourned by his dog. They said he was working part-time, taking real estate courses and attending university, with the goal of becoming a police officer and joining the anti-gang task force.

“That opportunity to live that life was stolen from him and our chance to watch him live that life was stolen from us,” they said. “All we have is our memories.”

The second victim statement was from a bystander who was among the first to try to help Malhi after he was shot. A recently passed Canadian victim bill of rights allows anyone who suffers physically or emotionally from a crime to submit a victim statement, Bellows said.

The witness, identified as N. Lalli in court documents, said in her statement that her life changed drastically that day because of post-traumatic stress, chronic fatigue, sleep problems and fear of leaving the house alone she still suffers.

She said she was terrified to go near the body but the 911 operator was asking her to check if Malhi was still breathing.

“I felt so out of control,” she said. “I couldn’t help the situation and that haunts me to this day.”

She said she dropped out of school and was without a place to live because she was so “mentally distraught” by the trauma. “It left me broken. I felt like I wasn’t safe anywhere.”

Bellows told court that Nguyens admitted to the crimes while writing on a white board at an Edmonton apartment in 2019. Nguyen thought he was talking cryptically to a close friend and drug trade associate, when in reality his friend had gone to the police, and police were secretly filming their exchange.

That friend, identified only as AB due to a publication ban, was the Crown’s most important witness. He testified he had worked in the drug trade with Nguyen for years and the accused admitted his role in both murders during conversations that included some hand signals and gestures. AB said he later agreed to become a police agent because he wanted out of the gang lifestyle and had begun to fear Nguyen and other Brothers Keepers.

AB testified Nguyen told him he was paid $100,000 for the Kang murder and $30,000 for the second hit in which Malhi was mistakenly killed.

Before the hearing on Thursday, Bellows read into court Nguyen’s criminal record. It was for an assault in 2022 while he was in custody awaiting trial, when he punched a corrections officer, breaking his nose.
